properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A snowstorm is expected Friday and Saturday. Maximum snowfall: 15 to 30 cm possible in the southeast, central and along the mid coast. Maximum rainfall: 10 to 15 mm possible over southeastern Labrador. Strongest winds: northerly near 80 km/h. Time span: Friday morning to Saturday evening. Remarks: Snow will begin Friday morning in southeastern Labrador and will spread elsewhere throughout the day. Precipitation will likely change over to rain for southeastern areas on Friday night, with snow persisting elsewhere. Strong northerly winds will develop behind the system on Friday night and will persist over most areas on Saturday. These winds will combine with fresh snow to cause significantly reduced visibilities in blowing snow. Conditions are expected to improve by Saturday evening. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-03-27T05:27:27-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-03-26T13:28:27-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0280793817.2020
Area: Norman Bay to Lodge Bay, Cartwright to Black Tickle, Rigolet and vicinity, Nain and vicinity, Upper Lake Melville, Eagle River
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow and rain expected tonight and Friday. Total snowfall: 5 to 10 cm. Total rainfall: 10 to 20 mm. Strongest winds: southeasterly 80 km/h on Saturday, followed by southwesterlies near 80 km/h Friday night. Time span: tonight until Friday evening. Remarks: Snow will begin this evening in the south and spread elsewhere through the night. Precipitation will change over to rain by Friday afternoon or evening. The rain will be accompanied by temperatures several degrees above freezing, resulting in snow melt and pooling water. The rain is expected to taper to flurries Friday night. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-03-27T05:11:20-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-03-26T13:12:20-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2890792178.2020

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A low pressure system from Quebec will move through the Davis Straight tonight. Very strong northeast winds with gusts to 100 km/h are expected late this afternoon and early this evening. ### Wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.
Expires: 2020-03-27T00:17:57-00:00

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Mixed precipitation today and tonight. Total snowfall: 5 to 15 cm. Maximum wind gusts: northeasterly up to 60 km/h. Locations: central Nova Scotia. Time span: this morning until Friday morning. Remarks: Snow may mix with rain or ice pellets this afternoon then end overnight. Should the system track further west the total snowfall amounts could be higher. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
Expires: 2020-03-27T05:59:42-00:00

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Hazardous winter conditions are expected. Total snowfall: 15 to 30 cm. Freezing rain: 2 to 5 mm possible. Maximum wind gusts: northeasterly up to 70 km/h. Les Suetes winds up to 80 km/h. Locations: eastern Nova Scotia, including Cape Breton. Time span: this afternoon until Friday afternoon. Remarks: Snow will spread northward this afternoon then transition to a mix of ice pellets or freezing rain this evening and overnight. Freezing rain is expected to change over to rain mainly over eastern Cape Breton before switching back to snow Friday afternoon. Flurries will persist Friday afternoon and combine with strong northwesterly winds which could give reduced visibilities in snow and blowing snow. Flurries will taper off Saturday morning. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become icy and slippery. Winter storm warnings are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
Expires: 2020-03-27T06:01:46-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-03-26T14:02:46-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2250178087.2020

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A snowstorm is expected. Total snowfall: near 25 cm. Maximum wind gusts: easterly near 70 km/h. Location: the Labrador Straits. Time span: beginning Friday morning until Friday evening. Remarks: Snow at times heavy will develop Friday morning and will combine with strong easterly winds to reduce visibility in blowing snow through the day on Friday. Precipitation is expected to change to rain Friday evening. ### Winter storm warnings are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 15 to 20 cm is expected. Locations: Buchans, Deer Lake, and Green Bay-White Bay. Time span: near midnight tonight until Friday afternoon. Remarks: Snow will transition to rain Friday afternoon. The rain will be accompanied by mild temperatures, resulting in snow melt and pooling water. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Heavy snow and very strong winds on Friday... Snow at times heavy combined with northeast winds gusting to over 70 kilometres per hour will affect the Lower North Shore beginning early Friday morning. Quickly accumulating snow and reduced visibilities could make travel difficult. A period of rain will be possible in Blanc-Sablon Friday evening. Conditions should improve early Saturday morning. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. properties.Title: Freezing Rain Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A period of freezing rain is expected this evening before precipitations change over to snow. Ice accretion amounts of 2 millimetres will be possible locally. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become icy and slippery. Freezing rain warnings are issued when rain falling in sub-zero temperatures creates ice build-up and icy surfaces. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.

properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds that may cause damage are expected or occurring. Maximum wind gusts: southeasterly near 100 km/h. Locations: the Avalon and Bonavista peninsulas. Time span: Friday morning until Friday evening. ### Loose objects may be tossed by the wind and cause injury or damage. Wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rain, heavy at times is expected. The frozen ground has a reduced ability to absorb this rainfall. Total rainfall: 15 to 25 mm, except as high as 50 mm for the Burin and Connaigre Peninsulas. Locations: the Avalon, Burin, Connaigre, and Bonavista Peninsulas, as well as Clarenville and Terra Nova. Time span: overnight tonight until Friday evening. Remarks: Snow will develop tonight before changing to rain by Friday morning. The rain will be accompanied by mild temperatures and strong easterly winds, resulting in significant snow melt. As a result, localized flooding is likely. The public is therefore advised to clear storm drains of ice and snow where possible ahead of the rain. ### Localized flooding in low-lying areas is possible. Rainfall warnings are issued when significant rainfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-03-27T05:07:57-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-03-26T13:08:57-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1668342334.2020

properties.Title: Winter Storm Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Total snowfall: 15 to 30 cm. Maximum wind gusts: northerly near 100 km/h Friday night. Locations: Postville-Makkovik to Hopedale. Time span: Friday night and Saturday. Remarks: Snow will develop near noon on Friday, becoming heavy at times Friday night. The snow will combine with strong northerly winds Friday night and Saturday to reduce visibility in blowing snow. Conditions are expected to improve Saturday night as the snow tapers off and the winds ease. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility in some locations. Winter storm watches are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

properties.Summary:
Description: Total snowfall: 10 to 20 cm. Maximum wind gusts: northerly up to 60 km/h. Locations: Halifax county- east of Porters Lake and Pictou county. Time span: beginning near noon until Friday morning. Remarks: Snow will transition to a mix of ice pellets and snow this evening with a risk of freezing rain.
